comment_text.mn88:3.1: “Single lotus” (ekapuṇḍarīka) appears as an auspicious epithet in a prayer for wealth at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.3.6.
comment_text.mn88:3.3: Different persons of the same name appear in SN 47.29 and Thag 1.41.
comment_text.mn88:8.3: The commentary says that Pasenadi’s actions were occasioned by the brutal murder of the wanderer Sundarī. Unscrupulous ascetics urged her to visit the Jeta Grove, then killed her so that blame would fall on the Buddha and his community (Ud 8.4). However, nothing in this sutta or its parallel at MA 214 supports this connection.
comment_text.mn88:9.2: Ānanda completed Pasenadi’s phrasing by adding “sensible” (viññūhi), since the Buddha’s conduct was in fact faulted by foolish ascetics and brahmins.
comment_text.mn88:10.1: This passage describes bad actions from five perspectives, showing that the Buddha’s analysis of morality was not based on a single factor.
comment_text.mn88:10.2: “Unskillful” (akusala) is an unwholesome quality of the mind, so this is the psychological dimension of immorality. What is unskillful is that which leads to the result opposite to that desired: we want happiness, but it leads to suffering.
comment_text.mn88:10.4: “Blameworthy” (sāvajja) behavior is that which makes one liable to criticism by others. This is the social dimension of immorality.
comment_text.mn88:10.6: “Hurtful” (sabyābajjha) refers to the fact that bad conduct is characterized by hurtful affliction both in its action and its consequences.
comment_text.mn88:10.8: “Results in suffering” (dukkhavipāka) through painful kammic consequences in this life or the future.
comment_text.mn88:10.10: Bad conduct does not just affect oneself, but reverberates in space, by harming others, and in time, by promoting the growth of even more unskillful qualities.
comment_text.mn88:14.1: The analysis is inverted for good conduct.
comment_text.mn88:17.2: Ānanda emphasizes that the Buddha does not just praise these things, he embodies them fully.
comment_text.mn88:18.10: The Chinese parallel at MA 214 has 繖, which supports the reading chatta (“parasol”). | For bāhitikā, I accept the commentary’s explanation that it means “foreign” or “imported” (cf. Sanskrit bāhya).

root_text.mn88:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn88:2.1: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn88:2.2: Sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena pubbārāmo migāramātupāsādo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
root_text.mn88:3.1: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo ekapuṇḍarīkaṁ nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā sāvatthiyā niyyāti divā divassa.
root_text.mn88:3.2: Addasā kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn88:4.1: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn88:4.2: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
root_text.mn88:4.3: ‘rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti;
root_text.mn88:4.5: ‘sace kira, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṁ karaṇīyaṁ, āgametu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando muhuttaṁ anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
root_text.mn88:5.1: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho so puriso rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho so puriso āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn88:5.2: “rājā, bhante, pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa pāde sirasā vandati;
root_text.mn88:5.4: ‘sace kira, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṁ karaṇīyaṁ, āgametu kira, bhante, āyasmā ānando muhuttaṁ anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
root_text.mn88:6.2: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā nāgā paccorohitvā pattikova yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn88:6.3: “sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa na kiñci accāyikaṁ karaṇīyaṁ, sādhu, bhante, āyasmā ānando yena aciravatiyā nadiyā tīraṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā”ti.
root_text.mn88:7.2: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena aciravatiyā nadiyā tīraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.mn88:7.3: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā nāgā paccorohitvā pattikova yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn88:8.1: Nisīdi kho rājā pasenadi kosalo paññatte āsane.
root_text.mn88:8.2: Nisajja kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn88:8.3: “kiṁ nu kho, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā tathārūpaṁ kāyasamācāraṁ samācareyya, yvāssa kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehī”ti?
root_text.mn88:8.4: “Na kho, mahārāja, so bhagavā tathārūpaṁ kāyasamācāraṁ samācareyya, yvāssa kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
root_text.mn88:8.5: “Kiṁ pana, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā tathārūpaṁ vacīsamācāraṁ …pe…
root_text.mn88:8.6: manosamācāraṁ samācareyya, yvāssa manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehī”ti?
root_text.mn88:8.7: “Na kho, mahārāja, so bhagavā tathārūpaṁ manosamācāraṁ samācareyya, yvāssa manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
root_text.mn88:9.2: Yañhi mayaṁ, bhante, nāsakkhimhā pañhena paripūretuṁ taṁ, bhante, āyasmatā ānandena pañhassa veyyākaraṇena paripūritaṁ.
root_text.mn88:9.3: Ye te, bhante, bālā abyattā ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā paresaṁ vaṇṇaṁ vā avaṇṇaṁ vā bhāsanti, na mayaṁ taṁ sārato paccāgacchāma;
root_text.mn88:9.4: ye pana te, bhante, paṇḍitā viyattā medhāvino anuvicca pariyogāhetvā paresaṁ vaṇṇaṁ vā avaṇṇaṁ vā bhāsanti, mayaṁ taṁ sārato paccāgacchāma.
root_text.mn88:10.1: Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti?
root_text.mn88:10.10: “Yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro attabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati.
root_text.mn88:10.11: Tassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
root_text.mn88:10.12: evarūpo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
root_text.mn88:12.4: “Yo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro attabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati.
root_text.mn88:12.5: Tassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
root_text.mn88:12.6: evarūpo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro opārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
root_text.mn88:13.1: “Kiṁ nu kho, bhante ānanda, so bhagavā sabbesaṁyeva akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānaṁ vaṇṇetī”ti?
root_text.mn88:14.1: “Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, kāyasamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti?
root_text.mn88:14.10: “Yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro nevattabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, na parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati.
root_text.mn88:14.11: Tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn88:14.12: Evarūpo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.
root_text.mn88:16.6: “Yo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro nevattabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, na parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati.
root_text.mn88:16.7: Tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn88:16.8: Evarūpo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro anopārambho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti.

root_text.mn88:18.3: Iminā ca mayaṁ, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa subhāsitena attamanābhiraddhā.
root_text.mn88:18.4: Evaṁ attamanābhiraddhā ca mayaṁ, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa subhāsitena.
root_text.mn88:18.5: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa hatthiratanaṁ kappeyya, hatthiratanampi mayaṁ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
root_text.mn88:18.6: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa assaratanaṁ kappeyya, assaratanampi mayaṁ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
root_text.mn88:18.7: Sace, bhante, āyasmato ānandassa gāmavaraṁ kappeyya, gāmavarampi mayaṁ āyasmato ānandassa dadeyyāma.
root_text.mn88:18.10: Ayaṁ me, bhante, bāhitikā raññā māgadhena ajātasattunā vedehiputtena vatthanāḷiyā pakkhipitvā pahitā soḷasasamā āyāmena, aṭṭhasamā vitthārena.
root_text.mn88:18.11: Taṁ, bhante, āyasmā ānando paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṁ upādāyā”ti.
root_text.mn88:19.1: “Ayaṁ, bhante, aciravatī nadī diṭṭhā āyasmatā ceva ānandena amhehi ca.
root_text.mn88:19.2: Yadā uparipabbate mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho hoti, athāyaṁ aciravatī nadī ubhato kūlāni saṁvissandantī gacchati;
root_text.mn88:19.3: evameva kho, bhante, āyasmā ānando imāya bāhitikāya attano ticīvaraṁ karissati.
root_text.mn88:19.4: Yaṁ panāyasmato ānandassa purāṇaṁ ticīvaraṁ taṁ sabrahmacārīhi saṁvibhajissati.
root_text.mn88:19.5: Evāyaṁ amhākaṁ dakkhiṇā saṁvissandantī maññe gamissati.
root_text.mn88:20.2: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn88:20.3: “handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bhante ānanda, gacchāma;
root_text.mn88:20.6: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo āyasmato ānandassa bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn88:21.1: Atha kho āyasmā ānando acirapakkantassa rañño pasenadissa kosalassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn88:21.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako ahosi raññā pasenadinā kosalena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
root_text.mn88:22.2: “lābhā, bhikkhave, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa, suladdhalābhā, bhikkhave, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa;
root_text.mn88:22.3: yaṁ rājā pasenadi kosalo labhati ānandaṁ dassanāya, labhati payirupāsanāyā”ti.
root_text.mn88:22.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn88:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn88:2.1: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn88:2.2: He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother, for the day’s meditation.
translation_text.mn88:3.1: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala mounted the Single Lotus Elephant and drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day.
translation_text.mn88:3.2: He saw Ānanda coming off in the distance
translation_text.mn88:3.3: and said to the chief minister Sirivaḍḍha,
translation_text.mn88:3.4: “My dear Sirivaḍḍha, isn’t that Venerable Ānanda?”
translation_text.mn88:4.1: Then King Pasenadi addressed a man,
translation_text.mn88:4.2: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Ānanda, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
translation_text.mn88:4.3: ‘Sir, King Pasenadi of Kosala bows with his head at your feet.’
translation_text.mn88:4.5: ‘Sir, if you have no urgent business, please wait an hour out of sympathy.’”
translation_text.mn88:5.1: “Yes, Your Majesty,” that man replied. He did as the king asked.
translation_text.mn88:6.2: Then King Pasenadi rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Ānanda on foot. He bowed, stood to one side, and said to Ānanda,
translation_text.mn88:6.3: “Sir, if you have no urgent business, it would be nice of you to go to the bank of the Aciravatī river out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn88:7.2: He went to the river bank and sat at the root of a certain tree on a seat spread out.
translation_text.mn88:7.3: Then King Pasenadi rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Ānanda on foot. He bowed, stood to one side, and said to Ānanda,
translation_text.mn88:7.4: “Here, Venerable Ānanda, sit on this elephant rug.”
translation_text.mn88:7.7: I’m sitting on my own seat.”
translation_text.mn88:8.1: So the king sat down on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn88:8.3: “Honorable Ānanda, would the Buddha engage in the sort of behavior—by way of body, speech, or mind—that is faulted by ascetics and brahmins?”
translation_text.mn88:8.4: “No, great king, the Buddha would not engage in the sort of behavior that is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”
translation_text.mn88:9.2: For I couldn’t fully express the question, but Venerable Ānanda’s answer completed it for me.
translation_text.mn88:9.3: I don’t believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by incompetent fools, without examining or scrutinizing, is the most important thing.
translation_text.mn88:9.4: Rather, I believe that praise or criticism of others spoken by competent and intelligent people after examining and scrutinizing is the most important thing.
translation_text.mn88:10.1: But Honorable Ānanda, what kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”
translation_text.mn88:10.3: “But what kind of bodily behavior is unskillful?”
translation_text.mn88:10.5: “But what kind of bodily behavior is blameworthy?”
translation_text.mn88:10.7: “But what kind of bodily behavior is hurtful?”
translation_text.mn88:10.9: “But what kind of bodily behavior results in suffering?”
translation_text.mn88:10.10: “Bodily behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both,
translation_text.mn88:10.11: and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn88:10.12: That kind of bodily behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”
translation_text.mn88:11.2: mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …
translation_text.mn88:12.4: “Mental behavior that leads to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both,
translation_text.mn88:12.5: and which makes unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn88:12.6: That kind of mental behavior is faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”
translation_text.mn88:13.1: “Sir, does the Buddha praise giving up all these unskillful things?”
translation_text.mn88:13.2: “Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”
translation_text.mn88:14.1: “But sir, what kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?”
translation_text.mn88:14.3: “But what kind of bodily behavior is skillful?”
translation_text.mn88:14.5: “But what kind of bodily behavior is blameless?”
translation_text.mn88:14.7: “But what kind of bodily behavior is pleasing?”
translation_text.mn88:14.9: “But what kind of bodily behavior results in happiness?”
translation_text.mn88:14.10: “Bodily behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both,
translation_text.mn88:14.11: and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn88:14.12: That kind of bodily behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”
translation_text.mn88:15.2: mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins?” …
translation_text.mn88:16.6: “Mental behavior that leads to pleasing yourself, pleasing others, and pleasing both,
translation_text.mn88:16.7: and which makes unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn88:16.8: That kind of mental behavior is not faulted by sensible ascetics and brahmins.”
translation_text.mn88:17.1: “Sir, does the Buddha praise embracing all these skillful things?”
translation_text.mn88:17.2: “Great king, the Realized One has given up all unskillful things and possesses skillful things.”
translation_text.mn88:18.2: How well this was said by Venerable Ānanda!
translation_text.mn88:18.3: I’m delighted and satisfied with what you’ve expressed so well.
translation_text.mn88:18.5: if an elephant-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one.
translation_text.mn88:18.6: If a horse-treasure was suitable for you, I would give you one.
translation_text.mn88:18.7: If a prize village was suitable for you, I would give you one.
translation_text.mn88:18.9: these things are not suitable for you.
translation_text.mn88:18.10: This imported cloth was sent to me by King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, packed in a parasol case. It’s exactly sixteen measures long and eight wide.
translation_text.mn88:18.11: May Venerable Ānanda please accept it out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn88:18.12: “Enough, great king. My three robes are complete.”
translation_text.mn88:19.1: “Sir, we have both seen this river Aciravatī
translation_text.mn88:19.2: when it has rained heavily in the mountains, and the river overflows both its banks.
translation_text.mn88:19.3: In the same way, Venerable Ānanda can make a set of three robes for himself from this imported cloak,
translation_text.mn88:19.4: and you can share your old robes with your fellow monks.
translation_text.mn88:19.5: In this way my religious donation will come to overflow, it seems to me.
translation_text.mn88:20.2: Then King Pasenadi said to him,
translation_text.mn88:20.4: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn88:20.5: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.mn88:20.6: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what Ānanda said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Ānanda, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn88:21.1: Soon after he left, Ānanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn88:21.2: and told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn88:21.3: He presented the cloth to the Buddha.
translation_text.mn88:22.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
translation_text.mn88:22.2: “Mendicants, King Pasenadi is lucky, so very lucky,
translation_text.mn88:22.3: to get to see Ānanda and pay homage to him.”
translation_text.mn88:22.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn88:22.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
